April 27, 2000
GameSpot
Online Gaming: Could This be the Year?
Maybe you heard the predictions that 1998 would be the year of the online game. Alan Dunkin tells us why it wasn't.
Alan Dunkin
Myth II Maker Bites Bullet
Bungie decides to take the high road with full recall of Myth II: Soulblighter; trusts gamers will come back for version 1.1.
Curt Feldman
No Love for the Dreamcast
Love de Lic, creators of the PlayStation RPG Moon, are working on a new Dreamcast title called Lack of Love. Scheduled for release in Winter '98, your character has to establish a base for human life on a distant planet while dealing with the local dangers.
Gamespot Staff
Kesmai Makes Crime Legal
Gamers get a sample of what it's like to be an original gangster with Kesmai's Legal Crime.
Harley Jebens
Kick Off the New Year Right
It's almost 1999 (as of this writing). So kick off the new year right by finishing Zelda one more time, beating Metal Gear, or playing some Sonic! Think of what a great year '98 was, and then ring in the new year with thoughts of what '99 will bring! Enjoy!
Gamespot Staff
Cool Dreamcast Stuff
TOKYO - If you're a gamer in Japan, you can get cool Dreamcast merchandise by buying games. To taunt you, there are pictures inside.
Yutaka Ohbuchi
UO Lawsuit Now History
Feuding parties agree to lay down their guns – settlement sees Electronic Arts paying San Jose Tech Museum US$15,000.
Curt Feldman
Tribes Fans Band Together
Dynamix's latest title, Starsiege Tribes, has been gaining more and more support since releasing before Christmas. So far, over 100 tribes have formed on the Net, and nearly 1000 gamers have applied to host servers.
Gamespot Staff
Titus Flies High
Titus nabs the Top Gun license for upcoming PC, N64, Dreamcast, and PlayStation titles.
Chris Johnston
Online Golf Ready To Putt
Think you have what it takes to beat other online golfers? Bet on yourself and you could win $9500.
Harley Jebens
NovaWorld Grows
NovaWorld ends on a good note for the year with one million new users.
Harley Jebens

Quake III Arena, Starcraft, and other games get ready to release for the Mac OS.
Micheal Mullen

Even after the bell has rung, the war of words continues. Read what Electronic Arts and Origin have to say today.

Marathon Infinity maker releases more shots of its first action title.

Harley Jebens
Acclaim Has a Turok Holiday
Acclaim says 1.4 million units of Turok 2: Seeds of Evil for the N64 have shipped. It says the title is becoming one of the top-selling N64 games of the holiday season. The Game Boy Color Turok 2 is also experiencing brisk sales, according to Acclaim.
Gamespot Staff
UO Online Reader Survey
Have the past months of legal wrangling between Electronic Arts, Origin Systems, and Bunboy (the one with the law degree) changed your opinion about Ultima Online?
Curt Feldman
SimCity Classic Web Bound
Can't find that old copy of SimCity in your closet? Maxis announces new Net version of the original - and it's free.
Micheal Mullen
PlayStation Emulator Comes to Mac
Connectix announces plans to release a commercial product that runs PlayStation games on a Mac.
Chris Johnston
Mages 2 Already?
Rage of Mages was released in October; Monolith is already getting ready to deliver the sequel.
Micheal Mullen
Game Bandits Hit Toys 'R' Us
A group of video bandits hit two Tampa Bay, Florida, Toys "R" Us stores on Monday and made off with over $10,000 in game cartridges. Clearwater police suspect that the banditos will attempt to sell the stolen goods in the area. Wonder if they have any Zelda carts....

Pokemon Yellow Coming to the US
The yellow version of Pokemon, called Pocket Monster Pikachu in Japan, has been confirmed for a US release in '99, according to Nintendo Power. Pokemon Yellow is more like the TV show with Pikachu following you from the beginning of the map.

Microsoft To Acquire FASA

Micheal Mullen
New Commandos Coming
Commandos: Beyond the Call of Duty is coming in March from Pyro Studios and Eidos Interactive. This eight-mission stand-alone follow-up to Commandos: Behind Enemy Lines features new mission objectives. It should retail for about US$30. Eidos says a one-level demo will be available soon at eidosinteractive.com.

989 Releases NCAA Final Four '99
989 Studios announced the release of its college basketball title, NCAA Final Four '99 for the PlayStation. The title features almost 300 NCAA Division 1 teams, 3D player and stadium models, TV-style camera angles, and play-by-play commentary by college basketball announcer Quinn Buckner.

Gamespot Staff
Hydra Adds Unreal Support
Red Mountain has added Unreal support to its new game server browser, Hydra-SB. New features include the ability to browse Unreal's meshes and skins in Hydra's Unreal user setup view. For more information about Hydra, head on over to http://www.madmzone.com/hydra_sb
Gamespot Staff
Torching ION Storm
Is ION Storm getting the last laugh? A web site hosting ill comments regarding ION's CEO gets its lights dimmed.
Alan Dunkin
Dungeons & Dragons, Finally!
TOKYO - Capcom has finally announced a firm release date for the Saturn Dungeons & Dragons Collection. The two-CD game will release on March 4 and will come in two configurations - one without the 4MB RAM cartridge for 5800 yen (US$51), the other with the cartridge for 7800 yen (US$69).

Gamespot Staff
Chron X Turns 3.1
Genetic Anomalies announced that Chron X 3.1 has been released. Improvements in the latest Internet collectable card game include a redesigned chat and matchmaking system, an enhanced help system for new players, and new single-user missions to add context to Chron X's back story.

Wanna see Acclaim's enactment of the 1999 AFC/NFC Championship games? Acclaim set up mock Championship games using its NFL Quarterback Club '99 title for the N64. The Minnesota Vikings and Denver Broncos won their respective games according to Acclaim's mock games. You can see highlights and results at www.acclaim.net.

Yutaka Ohbuchi
Rainbow Six Add-on
Eagle Watch, the add-on scenario disc for Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six, should be available by January 28. The disc will feature six new types of multiplayer games and seven new levels, including two new training levels. MSRP is about US$25.
Gamespot Staff
nVidia to Go Public
Sunnyvale, Calif.-based nVidia plans to go public next week. The initial public offering will sell roughly 3.5 million shares to the public at US$7 to $9 a share. NVidia is the 3D graphics chipmaker behind the Riva TNT and Riva 128, 3D accelerator chips used in cards like the Diamond Viper series.
Gamespot Staff
Microsoft Goes Mad, Again
Midtown Madness will compliment Monster Truck Madness and Motocross Madness.

Fly!'s Bird's-Eye View Gets Better
Upcoming flight simulator to include 50,000 square miles of satellite visual data.
Harley Jebens
New Eidos President
Keith Boesky will step down from the post of president of Eidos Interactive's US office effective Wednesday. He will be replaced by Rob Dyer, former Crystal Dynamics president. In another move at Eidos, former Crystal Dynamics VP of marketing Scott Steinberg will be appointed to the new position of senior vice president of marketing.

Micheal Mullen
Devil Dice Gets OPM Nod
THQ's Devil Dice (the US version of SCEI's Xi) won two awards from the Official U.S. PlayStation Magazine, the company announced today. The title won top honors as the Best Puzzle Game and Best Multiplayer Game of 1998.

Imagineer Plans Second DC Title
TOKYO - Imagineer will release a second Dreamcast game, Redline Racer, this spring. The last one was Incoming, and both are ports of PC titles. Redline Racer is a motorcycle racing game that takes place in the near future.

Moira Muldoon
Take-Two Distributes GBC Titles in Europe
Take-Two announced today that it has inked a deal with Majesco Sales to distribute ten of that company's Game Boy Color titles in Europe. Titles include Monopoly, Millipede, Frogger, Centipede, Breakout, Battleship, Missile Command, and three unnamed titles, which will be released between Feb. and Sept. 1999.
Gamespot Staff
Sony Tops, Nintendo Right Behind
Sony remains king of the video game hill, but Nintendo's fighting a good fight.
Chris Johnston
Sony Drops Price of Japanese PlayStation
TOKYO - On January 18, SCEI announced it is lowering the price of the PlayStation console in Japan. The new MSRP for PlayStation will be 15,000 yen (about $130) -- 3,000 yen cheaper than the current price. This move will be effective Jan. 23, the same day PocketStation is released in Japan.
Yutaka Ohbuchi

Ehrgeiz US Release Announced
Square and EA will be bringing 3D fighter, Ehrgeiz, to the US. The game is currently scheduled for a May release. The companies will be announcing additional plans for Final Fantasy VIII, as well as other US games next month.

UmJammer to the Rescue
It has been confirmed by SCEA that the official English title of PaRappa 2 is UmJammer Lammy (not the various ways we've been "translating" the Japanese title). The company confirms that the game will be available in the US in 1999 but could not comment further on a specific release date.
Gamespot Staff
WonderSwan Ready for Liftoff
Bandai's handheld gaming machine WonderSwan prepares for a March liftoff in Japan.
Chris Johnston
Heat Wave in South Park
Acclaim Entertainment announced today that its N64 version of South Park has exceeded expectations - it was the top seller during the week of Christmas and continues to be strong at retail into the New Year. A PC version is planned for March, as are international versions of the game.
Gamespot Staff

Harley Jebens
King of All Rentals

Chris Johnston
Sony Goes to the Super Bowl
SCEA announced Thursday that its 68-foot roaming tractor trailer (which they lovingly call the PlayStation Touring Attraction) will be at Super Bowl XXXIII in Miami beginning Jan. 22. It will be part of the Coca-Cola and Sprint NFL Experience, and will feature games both old and new, and football competitions on a 100-inch video wall.

videogames.com Rewind
Electronic Arts' recall of its Tiger Woods game and info on Acclaim's next wrestling game led the news this week. Check out our wrap-up of the big headlines.
Chris Johnston
NBA Jam on the GBC
Acclaim Sports will release NBA Jam '99 for the Game Boy Color in February for an MSRP of US$29.99. The title will work on both the GBC and the original Game Boy and features a two-on-two basketball game that includes all 29 NBA teams and five stars from each one.
Gamespot Staff
Harvest Moon 64 Gets its Date
Natsume's Harvest Moon scheduled to ship right after Harvest Moon for GBC.
Lauren Fielder
Konami Reveals Release Plans
Konami has confirmed its first half of 1999 releases, and it includes a few surprises.
Chris Johnston
Aliens vs. Predator Nixed for PS
Fox Interactive informed us Friday that work on the PlayStation version of its licensed monster mash first-person shooter (whew!) has been temporarily halted so that the developer can focus on the PC version. The company may decide to put it back into production at a later date.
Gamespot Staff
Talonsoft Notes
Battleground: Chickamauga ships and company provides details on its Battle Pack add-on disc for the Operational Art of War.
Alan Dunkin
New Railroad Tycoon II Map
Pop Top Software has released a brand-new map in response to gamers' enthusiasm for Railroad Tycoon II. The map, "Heartland," features the US Midwest, spans from 1935 to 1960, and is downloaded at the Gathering of Developers web site at www.godgames.com/RT2.
Gamespot Staff
Romero Replies
John Romero shows off the latest Daikatana shots and answers questions about problems at ION Storm. Well, sorta.
Gamespot Staff
Playback: The Week in Review
ION Storm, the upcoming SIN add-on, and news that SimCity 3000 went gold kept us busy this week.
Micheal Mullen
When Westwood Nox....
Lands of Lore maker already at work on new title, new franchise.
Alan Dunkin
DirectMusic Gets Milia Launch
Microsoft will be launching its long-awaited addition to DirectX, DirectMusic at Milia '99, in Cannes, France, next month. The company's Developer Relations Group will also be talking about DirectX 7.0 and will sponsor the first Milia Techno Party - watching programmers dance techno should be a story in itself.
Gamespot Staff
ION Storm COO O-U-T
Dallas developer trims executive team. Chief operating officer joins ranks of "former" ION employees.
Curt Feldman
EA Financials
Electronic Arts registers whopping increase in revenues.
Harley Jebens
Wrestling License to Genetic Anomalies
Chron X maker makes deal to bring a "collectible strategy game" based on the WWF to gamers.
Harley Jebens
ION Snoop Speaks
Read our interview with the Dallas Observer reporter who peeled back the facade of ION Storm.
Curt Feldman
Alpha Centauri Updated
Two demos from Firaxis tweak current Alpha Centauri demo.
Harley Jebens
Motorsport Simulations Launch
Online racing sims to come from new company – first game due this Spring.
Harley Jebens
Kesmai Goes High-Speed
Cincinnati Bell's ZoomTown to deliver high-speed games for locals.
Alan Dunkin
GT Files Suit Against Midway
Lawsuit alleges Midway took the money - US$35 million - and ran. GT accuses Midway of breach of contract and defamation.
Curt Feldman
E3 Brings Industry to LA
The IDSA made it official: The Electronic Entertainment Expo '99 will be held May 13-15 at the Los Angeles Convention Center and is open to members of the trade over 18 years old. For more information visit www.e3expo.com
Gamespot Staff
Star Fleet Battles Lives Again
Amarillo Design Bureau wrestles the Star Fleet Battles licenses from Task Force Games
Alan Dunkin
Alpha Centauri Officially Gold
Firaxis Games and Origin officially reported Monday that Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri has gone gold and will begin shipping soon in time for a February release - despite rumors to the contrary.
Gamespot Staff
Vigilante 8's Second Offensive
Activision fills up the gas tanks, the ammo, and the explosives for another ride through Vigilante 8.
Moira Muldoon
Castlevania's 64-Bit Comeback
Castlevania 64 hits stores beginning Tuesday. We get the absolute latest on the series from a reliable source at Konami.
Gamespot Staff
3Dfx Financials
Voodoo2 and Banshee video card maker 3Dfx reported that revenues for the quarter ending Dec 31 were US$60.7 million, up from last year's $22.3 million. Net income for the quarter was $2 million, flat compared with last year. Revenues for 1998 were up from $44 million the year before to $202.6 million. Net income for the year was $21.7 compared with last year's net loss of $1.7 million.
Gamespot Staff
RTIME Patent Approved
Interactive Networking Engine gets protection from US Patent Office.
Harley Jebens
Tanarus Goes to RedEye
Rights to the popular online action game are acquired by RedEye Interactive.
Alan Dunkin
Oni Update
Bungie stops by to show off its first third-person action title, Oni. Here's the latest. Screens included.
Micheal Mullen
New Releases
Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six: Eagle Watch from Red Storm Entertainment is due in stores January 26.
Gamespot Staff
Linux To Get Civilized
Civilization: Call To Power will be one of the first commercially available titles for the Linux OS.
Micheal Mullen
GT Files Suit Against Midway
Lawsuit alleges Midway took the money - US$35 million - and ran. GT accuses Midway of breach of contract and defamation.
Curt Feldman

Toys "R" Us, 7-Eleven, Frito Lay, and Pepsi-Cola all lend a hand in promoting ASC's racer.

Wipeout 3 For Real
Psygnosis has announced Wipeout 3 for the PlayStation. The game is due out at the end of the year.
Gamespot Staff

The NPD Group says that the video game industry hit an all-time high in 1998.

TOKYO - Tecmo releases more information about Monster Farm 2 in Japan.

4Kids confirms that next season we'll have 52 more episodes of Pokemon to look forward to.

Harley Jebens
Shadow Man's Dark Side
Voodoo-powered takes on a whole new meaning beyond hardware with Acclaim's horror-inspired FPS adventure title.
Micheal Mullen
Intense Readies Road Wars
Intense Entertainment Interactive, founded by ex-Imagic cofounder Paul Lombardi, has announced that its first game, Road Wars, will be released this April. The combat racer will sport 12 tracks, single- and multiplayer modes, and support for EAX, DirectX 6.0, 3DNow Technology, and force feedback.
Gamespot Staff
PocketStation Shortage
TOKYO - Sony scored big with the launch of the PocketStation, but now it seems like there aren't enough to go around.
Yutaka Ohbuchi
GT Gets Earful From Midway
Midway Games "disappointed" in GT Interactive's own "failures and shortcomings."
Curt Feldman
Sega Releases CART
TOKYO - Sega announces that this spring it will release a CART racing game for the Dreamcast: Super Speed Racing.
Yutaka Ohbuchi
Industry Grows and Grows
PC Data calls ‘98 one of the best; tallies double-digit growth from the previous year. Starcraft grabs top slot.
Harley Jebens
Maxis Expands 3000
SimCity 3000 to expand far beyond the 'burbs with new downloadable files.
Micheal Mullen
Sega PC Bundle
Bringing together two cartoon characters with attitude, Sega PC has released Sonic and Garfield Pack, which bundles Sonic the Hedgehog 3, Sonic and Knuckles, Garfield: Caught in the Act, and column puzzle game Baku Baku. The bundle carries an expected retail price of US$29.99.

Bethesda Gets Aggressor
Virgin's realistic Falcon sim touches down on Bethesda's airstrip.
Micheal Mullen
Soldnerschild S Still on Hold
Distracted by Destrega and WinBack, Koei puts Soldnerschild S on the back burner.
Gamespot Staff
Ink Dries on IMagic Deal
Interactive Magic announced that it has signed a definitive agreement to acquire MPG-Net and GameHub, which provides online games to AT&T's WorldNet Service. Interactive Magic says that, with this acquisition, it is now operating a Full Service Interactive Entertainment Destination Site, with chat, e-commerce, news, and interactive gaming.
Gamespot Staff
GameStorm Goes After Mac Gamers
Online gaming service makes its combat flight sim Air Warriors Mac compatible.
Gamespot Staff
Sony Defends PlayStation Turf
SCEA files a lawsuit against Connectix over its PlayStation emulator, and Connectix fires back saying, "It's on sale now."
Chris Johnston
3DO Hits With BattleTanx
The 3DO Company announced Wednesday that its first N64 game has entered the top ten lists at national retail stores like Wal-Mart, Toys "R" Us, Best Buy, Electronics Boutique, and Babbage's. 3DO continues to receive reorders for the game from major retailers, in some cases tripling the size of those orders when compared with the original.
Gamespot Staff
Sony Hurts, PlayStation Wins
Even as Sony Corp. announced sagging profits during the last three months of 1998, PlayStation sales remained strong. Sony blamed the rise in the value of the yen, price wars in overseas markets, and the general economic health of emerging markets for the reason it has recently lowered its future profit outlook.

Harley Jebens
Talk 'n Play Ships
ThrustMaster has shipped its Talk 'n Play multi-point voice conferencing software to retailers. Talk 'n Play allows up to four players to talk over the net while simultaneously playing games. It retails for US$29.95 and includes the Talk 'n Play software, 28 games from WON.net and a headset microphone.

Caesar III Milestone
Sierra Studios' Roman city builder, Caesar III, has reached over a quarter of a million sales worldwide. Since its September 1998 release, Sierra and Impressions Studios have released an enhancement pack and an assignment editor.
Gamespot Staff
Shootout '99 Canceled
Reportedly because of quality issues, 989 Studios' basketball title Shootout '99 has been canceled (originally planned for release this spring). Instead, the team will move to develop Shootout 2000, which will be released later this year.

Micheal Mullen
HotD2 for Dreamcast Confirmed
TOKYO - Japanese newspaper Houchi Shinbun reports that The House of the Dead 2 for the Dreamcast will be released on March 25. A gun controller, called Dreamcast Gun, will come packaged with the game for 7,800 yen (about US$68) or without for 5,800 yen (about $50). The Dreamcast Gun has a D-pad and VMS slot.

Curt Feldman
Sony Stings Competition
Sales of PlayStation units hit four million in November and December, 1998 alone. Sony says it sold close to a million of the four during the Christmas week. Sony says NPD stats put PS software sales at 18.1 million for the full year and that PlayStations can be found in one out of six US households.
Gamespot Staff
Street Fighter Alpha 3 On Hold
Capcom holds the presses on Street Fighter Alpha 3; still targeting April as release date for the home version.

Micheal Mullen
Smash Brothers Smashes to America
Nintendo of America confirmed with GameSpot News on Monday that its N64 character-based fighting game (developed by HAL Laboratories), Smash Brothers, will be released in the first half of 1999. While no specific date has been announced, it will not be called Smash Brothers in the US.

WCW Body-Slams N64 Market
THQ announced Tuesday that its N64 wrestling game WCW Nitro has made a dive off the top ropes and is landing squarely in game stores nationwide for an MSRP of US$49.99. It is the latest entry into THQ's megapopular line of console wrestling games.

Dreamcast Logo Tweaked for Europe
CANNES - Sega Europe has convinced Sega brass in Japan to paint the Dreamcast logo blue when the new system launches in Europe. The move is indicative of Sega Europe's overall Dreamcast strategy – to take every opportunity to give the Dreamcast an identity that European gamers can identify with.

Id Hacked
ZDNN UK has reported that id Software's web site was hacked early Tuesday morning. Apparently, someone replaced id's top page with a plea for the release of the infamous king of hackers, Kevin Mitnick. Id has since fixed the problem. No one has taken responsibility for the attack.

The Evil in Titus

Gamespot Staff
Taito Gives Out Arcade Board
Taito says it will release its graphics boards specifications to other video game developers, according to a Nikkei report. The release of the board's specs will help counter efforts by Sega to create an arcade industry standard. The first developer to take advantage of Taito's offering will release chess and card game software in Japanese arcades later this month.

Fisherman's Bait, Konami's entry into the fishing game market (and a port of the arcade game of the same name) is shipping now for the PlayStation and is arriving in stores this week. Redline Volunteers Needed

Harley Jebens
Barbie Beats on Rockett
Purple Moon, publishers of computer games for young girls, has reportedly closed its doors. Purple Moon was started in 1996 and received much of its funding from Microsoft cofounder Paul Allen. Its marquee title was Rockett's New School. Characterizing the company's demise, industry pundits said that stronger brands, such as Mattel's Barbie line of PC games, made it impossible for Purple Moon to survive.

RR Tycoon II Add-on
PopTop Software will deliver an add-on pak for Railroad Tycoon II this spring. The add-on, called The Second Century, will have an eighteen scenario campaign containing new, modern trains and engines, and new stand-alone maps. Sales of RTII are said to have reached 500,000 - virtually cementing a healthy future for the upcoming add-on.

Konami's latest game, Silent Hill for the PlayStation, will begin its invasion of North American souls before it is released in Japan. The company announced today that Silent Hill is now shipping to stores and should be available nationwide later this week. It won't be out in Japan until March 4.

Chris Johnston
EA Touts Madden Sales
According to Electronic Arts, Madden NFL 99 is the number-one selling PlayStation sports game of '98 in North America. Citing NPD Group numbers, the PlayStation version sold 1,128,366 units,100,000 more units than its closest competitor - and it also accounted for 57 percent of the PC football game category sales.
Gamespot Staff
Artdink Goes on Summer Holiday
Artdink, developer of such games as Mr. Domino and Tail of the Sun, is working on a sequel to its PlayStation game Aquanaut's Holiday. The game is scheduled for a July release in Japan, and has better graphics and more aquatic animals.

Magic and Mayhem Site Launches
Bethesda Softworks has officially launched the web site (www.magic-mayhem.com) for its upcoming RTS title, Magic and Mayhem. The title, being built by X-COM creator Mythos, was originally named Duel: The Mage Wars. It's scheduled for an early April release.

Pokemon Snap Captures Gamers
Pokemon Snap, Nintendo's latest Pokemon-themed game for the N64 will hit stores on March 21. Oddly, the title will be released on a Sunday instead of the normal Thursday Japanese release schedule. Pokemon Snap will be released in the US on June 28.

TOKYO - Genki announced that it will release Shutokou Battle on May 25 for the Dreamcast. Shutokou Battle is a racing game series with several games originally released on the PlayStation. Naturally, the game will be a sequel with graphic enhancements.

Re-Volt Races to Finish Line
Acclaim announced today that its R/C racing game Re-Volt will be out this fall for the PC, the PlayStation and the Nintendo 64. Developed by Probe, the game puts you behind the wheel of R/C cars and lets you race around various interactive environments.

THQ Has a Ball
June should see the release of billiards simulation Ultimate 8 Ball from THQ for the PlayStation and PC. The game will feature 14 pocket billiard games and a "School of Pool" mode that will feature tutorials, rules, trick shots and practice sessions. Mirage Technologies developed the game for THQ.

Chris Johnston
The Whole Story of Pokemon
Sybex will release a novel version of Pokemon in March, bringing gamers through the game's story as well as giving them valuable gameplay hints. Jason Rich, who penned Sybex's Zelda 64 novel returns for this Nintendo-authorized project. The novel will retail for about US$10.
Gamespot Staff
Konami's Next Dreamcast Titles
Konami is working on a few new Dreamcast games. Its untitled flight game is now known as Air Force Delta (tentative title, no release date). The company has also added one new game called Raizereet to its lineup. No details have been released regarding that game.
Gamespot Staff
GT Goes Hollywood
GT Interactive to move almost its entire operations to Burbank – home turf of its new CEO.
Curt Feldman
Enix Says Used Games Are OK
Enix will authorize retailers to sell used copies of its Tomb Raider III game beginning nine months after it hits store shelves in Japan. The company will charge resellers a seven percent royalty on the sale of the used game. It has yet to decide whether other games will be sold under these conditions as well.

Westwood Studios' Lands of Lore III has gone gold and should be in the hands of manufacturing on Thursday. Driver Gets Date
GT Interactive announced today that it will release the PlayStation version of Reflections' Driver getaway car chase game on July 8, with a PC version to follow in September. The game puts you in the role of the getaway driver as you race through the streets of four major US cities.

Gamespot Staff
Army Men 3D Released
The 3DO Company has shipped its PlayStation strategy game Army Men 3D to North American retailers. Players will get to control a small green plastic soldier named Sarge as he shoots first and asks questions later, dodges enemy fire, melts tan plastic enemies, or leads his army to enemy bunkers. Army Men 3D features a split-screen two-player mode and Dual Shock compatibility.

Sony to Show Third Arc
TOKYO - Sony will show the latest installment of its PlayStation RPG series, Arc the Lad at its booth on the floor of the Tokyo Game Show, which starts Friday. With the popularity of RPGs growing in the US, it's possible that we may see this third installment reach North American stores at some point in the future.

Capcom Plans Rival Schools Update
TOKYO - Capcom is reportedly working on a sequel to its Rival Schools PlayStation game, but not in the form of a new game, but a new disc called Revolution. The original disc (called Evolution) had several different extra features, including character customization and several mini-games.

Tarzan Swings to Game Boy Color
Activision informed GameSpot News on Tuesday that it will be publishing a Game Boy Color game based on the upcoming Tarzan animated film from Disney. The game will be released in conjunction with the film's debut this summer.

Chris Johnston
Shen Mue Value-price
According to reports from Japan, Sega's first chapter of Shen Mue will be set at a lower price point - 2800 yen (about US$25). This is good news, as gamers won't have to spend quite as much to get the first two parts, the first of which goes on sale August 5, the other before the end of the year in Japan.

Spyro in Japan
TOKYO - Spyro the Dragon is just days away from a release in Japan, and it's a little bit different than the US release. Insomiac's latest hits shelves in Japan on April 1 but includes some features not seen in the version released in the US - including a full Japanese localization and a PocketStation mini-game starring Sparks, Spyro's firefly companion.

Harley Jebens
More Free EverQuest for Players
Late Monday evening, 989 Studios announced that it would extend the one-free month trial by two weeks for all players registered by Wednesday, March 24. The company went on to apologize for ISP problems. From all indications here at GameSpot, the lines to EverQuest appear to be fully open and awaiting new explorers.

Activision announced late Monday that its highly anticipated strategy game, Civilization: Call to Power, has gone gold and has been sent to manufacturing. The game is expected to hit full distribution during the week of April 5.

Pokemon's Story
"Call me Pokemon." OK, so it needs work. We'll soon see if writer Jason R. Rich can do any better. His book, an officially licensed novelization of the Game Boy blockbuster Pokemon is due in stores before the end of the month. Pokemon: Pathways to Adventure will sell for US$9.99.

Infogrames Set to Acquire Gremlin

Alan Dunkin
High Stakes Burns Retail Rubber
Electronic Arts has released Need For Speed: High Stakes for the PlayStation. The new game features 15 licensed sports cars, including the BMW Z3 and Ferrari 550 Maranello, along with a revamped hot pursuit mode, ten tracks, and smarter AI. The Dual Shock-compatible game sells for US$49.95.
Gamespot Staff
Crave Hooks Up With Genki
Crave Entertainment of Los Angeles and Genki, Ltd. of Japan will join forces a la Square and Electronic Arts.
Gamespot Staff
Worldcraft Pro Cut?
Word on the web says that Sierra has cancelled Half-Life level builder, Worldcraft Pro. The tool was used to build several parts of Half-Life as well and was assumed to be on the way. GameSpot News contacted a Sierra representative who said she was not aware of any cancellation. We expect some sort of official word from Sierra tomorrow. One indication that the title has been cancelled is that it has been pulled from the Sierra Store site.
Gamespot Staff
Triple Play 2000 Ships
Electronic Arts announced on Wednesday that it had shipped Triple Play 2000 for the PC, PlayStation, and Nintendo 64. The latest homerun game from EA Sports features 750 MLB players, all 30 Major League stadiums (for PC and PS versions), and the ability to create custom players and teams.

Take-Two Interactive Software has filed a registration statement with the SEC for a proposed public offering of 5 million shares of common stock (a Secondary Public Offering). Of those shares, 3.5 million will be newly issued shares. Take-Two says that this offering has not yet become effective.

Elliott Chin
WebTV on Dreamcast
WebTV announced last week that it will begin sending Dreamcast users CDs with WebTV software, letting them use their DC's to connect to the service. Those who have registered their systems will receive the discs. Several Dreamcast-specific supplements will be offered in its programming, such as "Game Related Sites" and "Weekly Information on Games" to its DC customers.

989 Hits One Out of the Park
989 Sports announced Monday that its latest PlayStation baseball game, MLB 2000, will be available nationwide beginning tomorrow. The game sports all 30 MLB teams and players with new player and stadium models, expanded modes, and two-man commentary by Vin Scully and ESPN's Dave Campbell.
Gamespot Staff
Midway Racer Out
Midway's MicroMachines 64 Turbo has been released for the N64. The game lets up to eight players control miniature cars in environments like a breakfast table, pool table, or chemist's lab; take control of cars, tanks, ice cream trucks, and swamp boats .

GT Interactive's Microsoft Flight Simulator 98 add-on, Air Races, will be shipping to retailers sometime this April. The add-on features four air races, eight new airplanes, and a bonus DEA rescue. Air Races will sell for US$19.99.

Electronic Arts Revs Its Engines
EA said Wednesday that it has shipped its PlayStation racer Sports Car GT, retailing for an MSRP of US$44.95, to stores nationwide. With more than 45 licensed GT cars and four authentic tracks (with three fantasy tracks), EA hopes to bring something new to the racing category on console.

Latest Lode Runner Ships
Infogrames announced Tuesday that its Nintendo 64 title Lode Runner 3-D has shipped to stores nationwide. This 3D action puzzle game takes the classic gameplay of the original Lode Runner and puts everything into the third dimension, making the puzzles more complex than ever.

New Homeworld Site Launched
Sierra Studios and Relic Entertainment on Monday launched a new site dedicated to the upcoming space strategy and combat title, Homeworld (www.homeworld.net). The site features screenshots, newsletter sign-up, and information on the game, which is set for a June release.

Chris Johnston
One Million Rise of Rome Downloads
Microsoft announced that over one million gamers have downloaded the trial version of Age of Empires: The Rise of Rome from its official Web site. The add-on for Age of Empires was released last November to consumers and has since been bundled in the Age of Empires Gold Edition, which give gamers the original game and the add-on on for US$39.99

New Dark Vengeance Demo
WizardWorks' MacSoft division has released an updated Dark Vengeance Demo version 1.2 for Macintosh computers with a special demo-only level. The company has also release version 1.2 patch containing several bug fixes. For online gamers, Dark Vengeance Net Pack 1 adds multiplayer maps and a skin design tutorial to the full version of the software. http://www.wizworks.com/macsoft/darkv/darkv.html

Battle.net Champs
Season one of the Starcraft: Brood War World Championships concluded Thursday night. Sixteen players now move on to a final competition and the finals this August. The top three winners of the first season were X'Ds~Grrrr..., Kain-The-Feared, and CrazyJim~LiZaD.

LithTech Engine Gets KISSed
KISS: Psycho Circus, in development at Third Law Interactive (formerly Bloodshot), will use Monolith's LithTech 3D engine. Third Law is the Texas development house made up of former ION Storm artists who abruptly left ION late last year. The Gathering of Developers will publish the game.

The MSN Gaming Zone (www.zone.com) announced that it has added Parker Brothers Classic Card Games and Milton Bradley Classic Board Games to its free multiplayer offerings. Games in the two collections from Hasbro Interactive include Mille Bornes, Hearts, Gin Rummy Backgammon, Checkers, Chess, Connect-4, Dominoes, and more.

Jeff Gerstmann
Game Boy Color Price Cut?
Nintendo has said in a story posted by Reuters that the price of the Game Boy Color machines in Japan will be between 8,900 yen (about US$76) and 6,800 yen (about $58) on May 14. So far, more than 3.1 million units have been released, and the price-cut's intent is to help Game Boy gamers purchase the newer color machines. No word currently if the price cuts will come to the US.

One Million Montegos Shipped
Voyetra Turtle Beach has shipped more than one million Montego A3Dxstream sound cards, says the company. The A3D and DirectSound3D board features 64-voice wavetable synthesis and sells for about US$79. Turtle Beach's next card, the Montego II Quadzilla, is set for a spring release.

Sony Releasing New PlayStation Model
Sony will be releasing a new PlayStation model by the end of this month in Japan. The new model, the SCPH-9000, will not have a parallel port, which will hinder people from using external Mod chips to play pirated software. The new model will retail for 15,000 yen (about US$121).

Gran Turismo 2 Delayed
Reports from Japan have indicated that Gran Turismo 2 has been delayed, apparently due to the developers having some technical difficulties. Previously scheduled to release this summer, the game is now slated for a September release in Japan. There has been no official release date announced for the US yet.

Sam Kennedy
Nintendo Gets Mario Back
A three-foot statue of Nintendo's famous mascot, Mario, that was stolen from Nintendo headquarters in Redmond, Washington last week has finally surfaced. On Tuesday it was found under a blanket behind Nintendo's headquarters reports the States News Service. Police believe that whoever stole the statue was frightened by the media attention and decided to return it.

Activision announced on Wednesday that A Bug's Life has shipped for the Nintendo 64. The 3D adventure game takes players on a journey through a world based on the movie. A Bug's Life carries a suggested retail price of US$59.99.

Alaskan Boy Killed Over Nintendo
Reuters is reporting that a five-year-old boy shot his seven-year-old brother after they apparently argued over the use of their Nintendo. The incident occurred on Thursday in the small Yupik Eskimo village of Kotlik, 500 miles west of Anchorage, Alaska. No charges have been filed against the boy.

Hasbro Inc. (NYSE: HAS) began trading its common stock this morning on the New York Stock Exchange. Hasbro's brands include Playskool, Kenner, Tonka, Tiger, Parker Brothers, and Hasbro Interactive. At the end of the day, Hasbro's stock closed at 28 13/16.

NGPC SNK vs. Capcom Due December
The NeoGeo Pocket Color version of SNK vs. Capcom is slated for a December 22 release in Japan. It will be priced at 4300yen (about US$41) and will be compatible with the NGP Link cable and the Dream Link cable, which links the NeoGeo pocket and link cable together.

EA Sports has announced that Supercross 2000 for the Nintendo 64 has shipped to retailers. The game features 21 tracks, 13 stadiums, and 24 of the world's greatest Supercross and Freestyle Motocross riders.
